SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Doctor Dolittle is very interested in everything that the parrot is telling him, and he wants to learn more. Which quotation from the story supports this idea?

A.Choice: “‘Oh, we parrots can talk in two languages—people’s language and bird­language,’ . . .” (paragraph 6)

B.Choice: “‘You wouldn’t have understood me if I had.’” (paragraph 10)

C.Choice: “‘Now don’t go too fast—and I’ll write it down.’” (paragraph 11)

D.Choice: “‘Of course—of course,’ said the Doctor. ‘I’ll get you some at once.’” (paragraph 21)

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Which quotation from the story shows how Dr. Dolittle is helpful to the animals?

A.Choice: “‘Oh, there are plenty of animal­doctors,’ said John Dolittle, . . .” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “. . . Polynesia sat on the kitchen table giving him bird words to put down in the book.” (paragraph 12)

C.Choice: “‘There’s no reason why horses shouldn’t wear glasses, the same as people.’” (paragraph 20)

D.Choice: “And soon it became a common sight to see farm­animals wearing glasses in the country. . . .” (paragraph 24)

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 10.
:ibox:“What would have been the good?” said Polynesia, dusting some cracker­crumbs off her left wing. “You wouldn’t have understood me if I had.”
What do the sentences show about how Polynesia felt about Doctor Dolittle at the beginning of the story?

A.Choice: Polynesia felt Doctor Dolittle was a smart doctor.

B.Choice: Polynesia felt Doctor Dolittle was being rude to her.

C.Choice: Polynesia felt Doctor Dolittle had a lot to learn about the animals.

D.Choice: Polynesia felt that Doctor Dolittle needed to listen more closely to her.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: What is the meaning of the word s͟p͟e͟c͟t͟a͟c͟l͟e͟s as it is used in paragraph 20?

A.Choice: eyes

B.Choice: glasses

C.Choice: help

D.Choice: pills

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Based on paragraphs 20 and 21, which statement describes Doctor Dolittle as a person?

A.Choice: Doctor Dolittle lives over the hill.

B.Choice: Doctor Dolittle listens to his patients.

C.Choice: Doctor Dolittle is going blind in one eye.

D.Choice: Doctor Dolittle is happy as a doctor for people.

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “‘He has been treating me for six weeks now. . . .’” (paragraph 20)

B.Choice: “‘What I need is SPECTACLES.’” (paragraph 20)

C.Choice: “‘I am going blind in one eye.’” (paragraph 20)

D.Choice: “‘Of course—of course,’ said the Doctor. ‘I’ll get you some at once.’” (paragraph 21)

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 23.
:ibox:Then John Dolittle got a fine, big pair of green spectacles; and the plow­horse stopped going blind in one eye and could see as well as ever.
What does it mean that the plow­horse “could see as well as ever”?

A.Choice: He could see just like a blind horse.

B.Choice: He could see just like the other animals.

C.Choice: He could see better than he had in a long time.

D.Choice: He could see farther than before he had glasses.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how specific aspects of a text’s illustrations contribute to what is conveyed by the words in a story (e.g., create mood, emphasize aspects of a character or setting).
Content: Why did the author include the illustration of Doctor Dolittle and the horse in the story?

A.Choice: to show that the Doctor is testing the spectacles

B.Choice: to show that the Doctor asks the horse about his eyesight

C.Choice: to show that the Doctor is excited to be treating the horse

D.Choice: to show that the Doctor’s office is organized to help animals

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 15.
:ibox:“But animals don’t always speak with their mouths,” said the parrot in a high voice, raising her eyebrows.
What does the parrot mean by the sentence?

A.Choice: Sometimes animals are quiet.

B.Choice: Animals speak two different languages.

C.Choice: Animals use their whole bodies to share their feelings.

D.Choice: The Doctor should understand what animals are saying.

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which sentence states a central message of the story?

A.Choice: The Doctor learned to talk to the horse.

B.Choice: The animals do not always speak with their mouths.

C.Choice: The animals could talk to and understand each other.

D.Choice: The Doctor came to know and understand the animals.

Content: Which quotation from the story BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “‘Now listen, Doctor, and I’ll tell you something.’” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “‘But animals don’t always speak with their mouths,’ . . .” (paragraph 15)

C.Choice: “Then he gave up being a people’s doctor altogether.” (paragraph 18)

D.Choice: “‘Of course—of course,’ said the Doctor. ‘I’ll get you some at once.’” (paragraph 21)

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: Which of the following is a summary of the story?

A.Choice: Dr. Dolittle becomes an animal doctor because he likes animals more than people.

B.Choice: A bird teaches Dr. Dolittle to speak to animals, then he decides to be an animal doctor.

C.Choice: A horse needs a new pair of glasses, so Dr. Dolittle decides to learn how to talk to animals.

D.Choice: Dr. Dolittle becomes an animal doctor when he sees that animals are easier to cure than people.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Which quotation from paragraph 5 of “What Is Earth?” explains the importance of the equator?

A.Choice: “The equator is a make­believe line around the center of Earth.”

B.Choice: “Mapmakers use the line to divide Earth into two halves.”

C.Choice: “The northern half is called the Northern Hemisphere.”

D.Choice: “The southern half is called the Southern Hemisphere.”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 5 of “What Is Earth?”
:ibox:Mapmakers use the line to d͟i͟v͟i͟d͟e Earth into two halves.
What is the meaning of the word d͟i͟v͟i͟d͟e as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: circle

B.Choice: part

C.Choice: split

D.Choice: spot

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Based on the passage “What Is Earth?”, how does water impact life on Earth?

A.Choice: People drink water to survive.

B.Choice: Water is found in lakes and rivers.

C.Choice: All living things require water to live.

D.Choice: There is not enough water to support life.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Use information gained from illustrations (e.g., maps, photographs) and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding of the text (e.g., where, when, why, and how key events occur).
Content: According to the diagram in “What Is Earth?”, in which two months does the sun shine equally on the Southern and Northern Hemispheres?

A.Choice: June and December

B.Choice: December and March

C.Choice: September and June

D.Choice: March and September

SubTopics: Use text features and search tools (e.g., key words, sidebars, hyperlinks) to locate information relevant to a given topic efficiently.
Content: Why did the author include the information in the caption of the diagram?

A.Choice: to explain Earth’s seasons

B.Choice: to tell what causes Earth to tilt

C.Choice: to show the location of Earth’s equator

D.Choice: to show the reader how Earth orbits the sun

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 3 of Planet Earth.
:ibox:The mantle is covered with a thin layer of rock, called the c͟r͟u͟s͟t.
What is the meaning of c͟r͟u͟s͟t as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: Earth’s hottest layer

B.Choice: Earth’s inner mantle

C.Choice: the layer of rock around Earth’s core

D.Choice: the layer of rock around Earth’s mantle

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What is the purpose of the quotation from paragraph 4 of “What Is Earth?”
:ibox:From space, Earth looks like a blue marble with white swirls.

A.Choice: to show how water changes the color of Earth

B.Choice: to compare the size of Earth to an everyday object

C.Choice: to give a detailed description of what Earth looks like

D.Choice: to explain the effect of swirling clouds on weather on Earth

Content: Which quotation from “What Is Earth?” or the excerpt from Planet Earth has the same purpose as the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Four planets in the solar system are bigger than Earth.” (paragraph 1, “What Is Earth?”)

B.Choice: “Earth is the only planet known to have lots of liquid water.” (paragraph 3, “What Is Earth?”)

C.Choice: “The Sun keeps the planet warm.” (paragraph 2, “Excerpt from Planet Earth”)

D.Choice: “The rocks here are so hot that they are slightly squishy.” (paragraph 3, “Excerpt from Planet Earth”)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the most important points and key details presented in two texts on the same topic.
Content: Which TWO quotations from “What Is Earth?” and the excerpt from Planet Earth support the idea that Earth is the only planet with living things?

A.Choice: “Four planets in the solar system are bigger than Earth.” (paragraph 1, “What is Earth?”)

B.Choice: “It is the third­closest planet to the sun.” (paragraph 1, “What is Earth?”)

C.Choice: “Earth has been called the ‘Goldilocks planet.’” (paragraph 2, “What is Earth?”)

D.Choice: “. . . Earth . . . has the right mixture of heat, air and water.” (paragraph 2, “Excerpt from Planet Earth”)

E.Choice: “The middle of the planet is called the core.” (paragraph 3, “Excerpt from Planet Earth”)

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: What is the main idea of BOTH “What Is Earth?” and the excerpt from Planet Earth?

A.Choice: Earth moves around the Sun.

B.Choice: Earth is made up of two hemispheres.

C.Choice: Earth has an environment necessary for life.

D.Choice: Earth is made of different gases such as oxygen.

SubTopics: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the narrator or those of the characters.
Content: How does the author show that Peter is confused at the beginning of the story?

A.Choice: by using dialogue to show his feelings

B.Choice: by explaining how he talks to Lightfoot

C.Choice: by providing descriptions to show his actions

D.Choice: by comparing his thoughts to Lightfoot’s thoughts

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: Which quotation from the story supports the idea that Peter Rabbit thought Lightfoot was lying?

A.Choice: “. . . whom he always had believed quite as gentle, harmless, and timid as himself.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Peter blinked very hard.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “‘How can anything hard like those antlers grow?’” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “Peter watched in silence for a few minutes.” (paragraph 16)

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Which inference about Peter is supported by the story?

A.Choice: Peter wants to have antlers like Lightfoot.

B.Choice: Peter would like to see Lightfoot’s secret place.

C.Choice: Peter feels confused by Lightfoot’s new antlers.

D.Choice: Peter does not trust Bossy the Cow after talking to Lightfoot.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 9.
:ibox:“How can anything hard like those antlers grow? And if those are new ones, where are the old ones? Show me the old ones, and perhaps I’ll believe that these are new ones.”
Which sentence describes how Peter feels when he speaks the sentences?

A.Choice: Peter is confused by Lightfoot’s new antlers.

B.Choice: Peter is angry that Lightfoot has new antlers.

C.Choice: Peter is excited that Lightfoot has new antlers.

D.Choice: Peter is surprised to see Lightfoot’s new antlers.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentences from paragraph 1.
:ibox:Peter Rabbit was p͟u͟z͟z͟l͟e͟d. He stared at Lightfoot the Deer a wee bit suspiciously.
What does p͟u͟z͟z͟l͟e͟d mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: built

B.Choice: confused

C.Choice: looked upon

D.Choice: pieced together

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: Why did the author include several examples throughout the story of Peter questioning Lightfoot about his antlers?

A.Choice: to help the reader understand Peter’s character

B.Choice: to help the reader understand their special friendship

C.Choice: to help the reader understand the process of how Lightfoot’s antlers changed

D.Choice: to help the reader understand why Lightfoot stopped explaining his new antlers to Peter

SubTopics: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate conversational, general academic, and domain-specific words and phrases, including those that signal spatial and temporal relationships (e.g., After dinner that night we went looking for them).
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Read the sentence from paragraph 5.
:ibox:Peter was sitting up very straight, with his eyes f͟i͟x͟e͟d on Lightfoot’s antlers as though he never had seen them before.
What does f͟i͟x͟e͟d mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: open

B.Choice: repaired

C.Choice: uninterested

D.Choice: unmoving

Content: Which phrase from the sentence supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “was sitting up”

B.Choice: “very straight”

C.Choice: “on Lightfoot’s antlers”

D.Choice: “never had seen”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 9.
:ibox:“What kind of a story are you trying to f͟i͟l͟l͟ ͟m͟e͟ ͟u͟p͟ ͟w͟i͟t͟h?”
What does Peter Rabbit mean when he says f͟i͟l͟l͟ ͟m͟e͟ ͟u͟p͟ ͟w͟i͟t͟h?

A.Choice: read to

B.Choice: confuse

C.Choice: convince

D.Choice: pour into

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: What lesson does Lightfoot try to teach Peter Rabbit in the story?

A.Choice: Cows and deer are similar.

B.Choice: Having patience is difficult.

C.Choice: Growing antlers takes time.

D.Choice: One should trust his friends.

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which sentence states a central message of the story?

A.Choice: One should question their friendships.

B.Choice: A person cannot always believe what their friends say.

C.Choice: A person should have proof before they believe something.

D.Choice: One does not always have to see something for it to be real.

Content: Which quotation from the story supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “He didn’t like to think it of Lightfoot, . . . But what else could he think?” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “‘I’ve seen Bossy the Cow all summer and I know she has got the same horns. . . .’” (paragraph 9)

C.Choice: “‘I have a new pair every year.’” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “‘Where did you leave your old ones and when did they come off?’” (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 1.
:ibox:Egyptian hieroglyphs made a h͟a͟n͟d͟s͟o͟m͟e background behind the queen.
What does the word h͟a͟n͟d͟s͟o͟m͟e mean as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: beautiful

B.Choice: brave

C.Choice: stiff

D.Choice: strong

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Read the sentence from paragraph 3.
:ibox:In a͟n͟c͟i͟e͟n͟t Egypt, the people made boats, sails, candles, cloth, mats, and more with it.
What is the meaning of the word a͟n͟c͟i͟e͟n͟t as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: hot

B.Choice: busy

C.Choice: far away

D.Choice: very old

Content: Which quotation from paragraph 5 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Egyptian kings didn’t want to share this invention.”

B.Choice: “They decided the making of papyrus sheets should be a secret.”

C.Choice: “It didn’t take too long, however, before others figured out how to copy this Egyptian invention.”

D.Choice: “After several thousand years of use, there wasn’t enough papyrus left to keep up with the demand.”

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Use information gained from illustrations (e.g., maps, photographs) and the words in a text to demonstrate understanding of the text (e.g., where, when, why, and how key events occur).
Content: Why did the author include the illustrations in the passage?

A.Choice: to help the reader see how to make papyrus sheets

B.Choice: to help the reader understand the length of papyrus sheets

C.Choice: to help the reader see the crisscross pattern of the reeds on the sheets

D.Choice: to help the reader understand the importance of hammering the sheets

SubTopics: Use text features and search tools (e.g., key words, sidebars, hyperlinks) to locate information relevant to a given topic efficiently.
Content: What would be a good title for the diagram?

A.Choice: Creating Papyrus Sheets

B.Choice: Writing on Papyrus Paper

C.Choice: How to Cut Papyrus Scrolls

D.Choice: Papyrus Paper Past and Present

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: What question is answered by paragraph 10?

A.Choice: Where does papyrus come from?

B.Choice: How are the sheets of papyrus cut?

C.Choice: Where should the papyrus plant be cut?

D.Choice: How are sheets of papyrus held together?

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: How is the section titled “Get Ready to Write . . .” different from paragraphs 1–5?

A.Choice: Paragraphs 1–5 are a narrative about papyrus and “Get Ready to Write . . .” is information on the papyrus plant.

B.Choice: Paragraphs 1–5 are a narrative about papyrus and “Get Ready to Write . . .” is about how to make papyrus paper.

C.Choice: Paragraphs 1–5 give information on the papyrus plant and “Get Ready to Write . . .” is about how to make papyrus paper.

D.Choice: Paragraphs 1–5 list the problems of using papyrus as paper and “Get Ready to Write . . .” is information about the papyrus plant.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: What is the main idea of paragraphs 3–5?

A.Choice: Papyrus was a secret kept by Egyptian kings.

B.Choice: Papyrus was copied by other Egyptian inventors.

C.Choice: Papyrus was a paper used by ancient Egyptians.

D.Choice: Papyrus was grown by an Egyptian scientist in 1965.

SubTopics: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the author of a text.
Content: What is the author’s point of view in the section titled “Get Ready to Write . . .”?

A.Choice: She wants to describe how papyrus was used as paper in 1965.

B.Choice: She wants to explain how to make paper out of papyrus.

C.Choice: She wants to compare papyrus to regular paper.

D.Choice: She wants to show how papyrus was a plant.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: The following question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then answer Part B.
Read the sentence from paragraph 6.
:ibox:Today, Dr. Ragab’s family continues the t͟r͟a͟d͟i͟t͟i͟o͟n of making papyrus “paper.”
What is the meaning of the word t͟r͟a͟d͟i͟t͟i͟o͟n as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: education

B.Choice: plan

C.Choice: position

D.Choice: practice

Content: Which word from the sentence helps the reader understand the meaning of the word t͟r͟a͟d͟i͟t͟i͟o͟n?

A.Choice: continues

B.Choice: family

C.Choice: making

D.Choice: today

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: In the passage, the reader learns that papyrus becomes used less over time. What causes this change?

A.Choice: It became thinner and more difficult to use.

B.Choice: It became difficult to find and keep a supply.

C.Choice: It became easier to make by people in the local areas.

D.Choice: It became a secret no one wanted to share with the world.

SubTopics: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate conversational, general academic, and domain-specific words and phrases, including those that signal spatial and temporal relationships (e.g., After dinner that night we went looking for them).
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 6.
:ibox:In 1965, an Egyptian scientist named Dr. Hassan Ragab began to grow papyrus and make papyrus sheets, just like his a͟n͟c͟e͟s͟t͟o͟r͟s had done thousands of years ago.
Which word could replace a͟n͟c͟e͟s͟t͟o͟r͟s as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: bosses

B.Choice: children

C.Choice: friends

D.Choice: relatives

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: Read the following prompt and write your complete response in the space provided.

:ibox:You have read an excerpt from “The Adventures of Grandfather Frog,” a story about an old, wise frog who decides to go out into the Great World to learn something new. Explain how Mr. Toad and Jerry Muskrat help Grandfather Frog decide to go into the Great World. What did each character do to push Grandfather Frog to make this choice? Provide key details and examples from the story to support your writing.

Your writing will be scored based on the development of ideas, organization of writing, and language conventions of grammar, usage, and mechanics.
Write your response for the prompt in the space below.
